captions.text: Hey guys Chris fix here and today I am going to show you how to replace the tie-rod ends

both the outside and the inside tie rod
ends

very important for your steering and for
your toe
alignment so I am going to show you how to do that now, so there is your tie rod
you can see I can move this with my hand, it is very old
300,000 miles will do that to it. It is amazing they made it that far
so here are all of the tools you are going to use for this job.  You need

a couple wrenches, screwdrivers, flathead
screwdrivers
some lock tight thread glue

a torque wrench, a breaker bar, hammer,
rubber mallet, needle nose plyers
and a grease gun and the new tie rod
inside and outside.  You will also need an inner tie-rod tool

which is this right here. You can rent
this for free Autozone or Pepboys or
whatever the main part stores you use.
So what you are going to do is take your needle nose plyers
and open up the cotter pin so that it is straight.
And once the cotter pin is straight, grab the other side
and start pulling it out.
there we go
one cotter pin pulled out.
Now you can put a 19mm or 3/4 ratchet or wrench on this.
A nice long break a bar will help.
Once you break it loose, use your ratchet
and take the castle nut off.

now there's a tool that you can use that
goes in here and pry's this up, but
what I am going to do is take this castle nut and I'm gonna flip it over
so screw it in this way.
Good! Now I am going to take a hammer, I'll use a rubber mallet just to be safe
and I will pop it up maybe up
[Metallic Hammering Noise]
There we go.

The tie rod end is out. Now this is the
interesting part

there's a nut here that they use for
your alignment
because this affects your alignment.
What you want to do is put your tie rod in and now we can unscrew this nut.
You just want to break that loose like that and now we can take this out and
you can see this spins freely... From the bottom here

that's that the bottom which is pointing down,
you wanna take this
and you want to spin it.
So that is one, two... and you want to count how many spins it takes to get this off.
three, four, five, six...
18, 19... So twenty spins total,

it took me 20 spins you get this off and
when you put the new one on

you want to count twenty spins and the
reason why is it that your alignemnt
isn't completely out of alignment. You are still gonna have to get the car aligned
after you change this

but at least your alignment wont be so bad
that it's dangerous to drive

so you could see this moves around very
easily and has a little bit of play inside and outside
so the inner tie rod end also needs to be changed, but we were going to do that anyway
Now you can see, so the tie rod end works by steering the car when you turn the steering wheel
it turns this which allows the car's
wheel to turn
it goes all the way up into here, and now there is a boot here

and you want to use a pliers to get
this off and there's also
a another one these except you have to break the clamp with a screwdriver,
and I will show you that now.
but that is all the way in the back
so for this one, you just get the
the same needle nose as before
squeeze it and pull it out.
all this is, is a little clamp to keep the boot on.

Now little trick here is to use a
screwdriver a flat head

and just bend this up a little bit. Not
too much because we are re-using the boots
you just want to get it under here so we can spray some silicone or grease
to make it slide off easier
Now we just go in here, with a flathead screwdriver,

carefully, without breaking the boot it's
like that
just like that... You see how the boot is up... get your WD40 or whatever
some type of grease or silicone, which is what I am using
and just spray it in there.
and that will make the boot come off a lot easier because surprisingly, the boot is on there tight.
the next thing we are going to do
you see that clip right down there
there is a clip right there, and what you are going to do is push the screwdriver in and turn the screw driver to open the clip
it's hard to see but I think you will get the idea when I do it.
You just get the screwdriver in there
and turn... [clicks open] and you can see
it opened up, and now we can take the boot off.
[Spray]
OK, unscrew this nut here so we can take the boot off.
take the bolt off, slide off your clamp,
now take your bellows boot off

good, so we're gonna wanna quickly
inspect this to make sure there are no cracks

looks good, so when we're installing
it there is this right here

that's gonna slide over the tube
in there
its going to slide over that tube which connects to the other tie rod on the other side of the car

it allows for venting... so you can see the
tube on the top right and then you could
see the

inside tie rod right there with its ball
joint that is

very loose, so now we're going to take
that out.
so here is the actual tie rod
the inside tie rod
and I just want to show you what is going to happen so that you completely understand this.
so here is your adapter
your adapter is going to fit on here, just like that.
So when you turn the tie rod too, it grabs the end and turns it

otherwise it would be hard to get a wrench
on here. You can do it you just have to see if you have

access. The other thing to remember is
that there's sometimes a pin in this
so you have to take that pin out and that is what I am going to go check for now.
You can see on this tie rod end there is a pin right here and this has to come off
so you take a flat-head screwdriver
you get underneith it, and you pry it out.
you could see I'm just prying this up
If you can't get your screwdriver under here that easy, you could use a hammer and the screwdriver
and just get it to indent a little bit. So you could see
I'm almost ready to just knock this thing out
Knocked it right out. So now we can unscrew this.
Just like I showed you, your adapter piece goes right on top just like that.
take your tie rod tool
slide it in
and then you put your ratchet on there.
Once you break it loose like that
this thing should come right out, and if it is not coming out easily
remember there's that pin in there that needs to come out first
here are the two tie rods side by side
the next thing you are going to do is make sure they are the same size
the new one is a little bit longer
so that is going to affect the toe but

we're getting an alignment anyway so
doesn't matter. Now you can see
I can move this really easily, that is the old one
a single finger can move it around
the new one... I cant even move it
it'll have to be on the car for me to move it. I'm going to get some blue thread lock

this is the removable type
and I am going to put a little inside here
Just like so... Now lets install the new tie rod.
never took the old clamp out
the clamp you have to break, take that out.
here is the pin
it's not really reusable
take our new tie rod
and just tighten it by hand
Once you cannot tighten it by hand anymore,
Once you cannot tighten it by hand anymore,
get your tie rod tool
put it over the tie rod
slide it on
then get your torque wrench,
for my vehicle it says torque to 66 to 74ft-lbs of torque
I am going to torque it to 70ft-lbs
Once you torque it, you are set.
I am under the car and you can see the hole for the pin.
That is where you push the pin in... I put a screwdriver head against the pin
like this... and then I used a hammer to lightly tap it in.
and now it's all the way in.
So remember before I was talking about the clip

that is a sacrificial clip that holds on
the boot that you put your screwdriver in here
and you twist and the clip opens up, well, it is only a one use clip

so either you get a new one, which
they're hard to find,

but one temporary solution is to use
zip-ties

I went to go get a bellows boot kit
to see if it comes with new clips and
and it came with zip ties
so although it sounds kinda cheap, the boot doesn't really move

very much so it's okay to use a zip-tie...
It is not a permanent solution like this metal clip
because a zip tie will eventually get
brittle but until you can find a metal clip
zip ties are a good way to go, and that is what I will use.
You can also use stainless steel hose clamps with the nut that tightens it down
The hose clamps are hard to find that are narrow enough to fit the boot.
so zip ties work nicely in this situation.
Now we are going to put the new boot on.
You see that at the end of my screwdriver?
There is that tube and you want to make sure you push
this into that tube... So I actually tightened up the zip ties
first up on the the boot, now I am going to slide the boot in.
so now you just tighten the zip ties after you push the boot all the way on
good
Now we take our clamp, and bring it up
Put it on just like that and we are done with the boot.
so here is the new tie rod end
we can see the new is nice and sturdy

the old one moves really easily. It comes
with all the accessories

the screw in the top, a pin, and a nut. So
they give you a new nut
but it's kinda small, so I will use the old one because it's thicker.

has more thread on it so it will lock
better.
Just screw that old nut back on...
It took me 20 spins to get this
off so I will put it back on with 20 spins.
It is threaded so we will start counting

20 spins, face it down. Now will tighten
our nut up here.
We want the nut to push against
the new tie rod end.
This will keep it from moving.
I am going to put the grease valve on. Just screw it in by hand first.
Now I will use a 5/16 inch wrench
And just snug it down.
You dont want to tighten this too much.
Just enough, and that is good.
Now we will put this into the knuckle.
Line it up...
push it through...
Get your new castle nut and screw it on.
That is how it should look.
I set the torque to 46ft-lbs
And tighten it until it clicks...
[Click]

when it clicks once, you do it again and
in that statement
[Click]
And then that is tight enough.
we will now take our cotter pin and send it though the hole.
good
Now just bend the cotter pin around the castle nut
Like so
Now we're gonna lube this up
Put the grease gun on there and pump it with grease.
you can see the rubber expanding
and once it expands like that, that means you have enough grease in there
and you just finish the job!
You just changed the inner and outter tie rod ends!
Now go get your car aligned.
If the video was helpful, give it a "thumbs up"
and if you like how to videos, and this was good, then subscribe.
I upload how to videos weekly and it will help you save some money
and fix your own car.
If you want to see other "how to" videos, I will have links in the description.
You can also click on any of the videos on the screen.

title: How to Change Tie Rods (inner and outer tie rod ends)

comments.text:
Very nice. Even though I am not going to change my Tie Rod Ends, I now know 
what is involved. Thanks for the video. It does give me confidence to do 
the job myself.﻿
comments.author: Frank LeVasseur

comments.text: +Frank LeVasseur Thanks Frank! That is the goal! Glad you liked the video!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: That pin looked like a pop rivet.﻿
comments.author: BubaJ1000

comments.text: +BubaJ1000 It does!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: I will be doing this in the am,thanks for the video.﻿
comments.author: Ravensfolyfe410 Yadig

comments.text: +Ravensfolyfe410 Yadig Awesome! Let me know how it goes!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: you made that look way easier then what it is lol﻿
comments.author: thug8200

comments.text:
+thug8200 It really is that simple. What I did in the video is what I did 
in real life haha.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
As usual real nice video presentation giving me the inspiration to do the 
job. Used Mevotech tie rods ( inner & outer ) per your suggestion. Had some 
real problems though with the "powerbuilt" tool from Autzone not grabbing 
the flats of the inner tie rod and always falling off. Why is it always so 
difficult to find an answer about torque  settings no matter what I am 
replacing ?﻿
comments.author: Ryk McCarty (G Dawg)

comments.text:
+Ryk McCarty Awesome! Thank you very much bud and I am glad you did the 
job! I dont know why they make it so hard to find torque specs. I wish 
there was a website that had all of them in one place!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Great video, ill be refering back to it whem i do mine. Thanks for taking 
the time to make it. Subscribed"﻿
comments.author: c230benzito

comments.text:
+c230benzito Awesome! Glad you subbed and welcome aboard! Let me know how 
it goes!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: Hey Chris! What kind of car did you use to replace those parts?? ﻿
comments.author: Odalis Inoa

comments.text:
Alright cool! So after you take out the inner tie rod, is it necessary to 
put that small silver pin back into the new tie rod? I got everything down, 
I don't get what that pin is for? Maybe hold it in place? Thanks Chris!
comments.author: Odalis Inoa

comments.text:
+Odalis Inoa This was a ford windstar but the process is basically the same 
for any make and model that has this style tie rod.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Wow I'm impressed. Best teacher ever. Explains every detail, reason, why 
and how. Shows all aspects. Bravo, well done :)﻿
comments.author: jeff larsen

comments.text: +jeff larsen Thanks a lot Jeff! I do my best!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
To change the Ball Joints, Inner and Outer rods and bushings...whats the 
order you recommend me to do?﻿
comments.author: Joey Cymbals

comments.text:
+Joey Cymbals Go on the PT Cruiser forums and search for torque specs. That 
is what I do when I dont have a service manual.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Ok, how I know the specific torque of everything  to use a Torque Wrench? I 
don't have the owners manual, is a used PT Cruiser 2003.
comments.author: Joey Cymbals

comments.text:
+Joey Cymbals Do them all at once. Take the tie rods out, remove the ball 
joints and bushings, and then reverse. Work with the job so it is easiest 
for you.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
whats up Chris
props to you for making this great video. I was wondering where do you find 
your torque specification?﻿
comments.author: Julio Amaya

comments.text:
How tight should the castle nuts be? I changed mine but am a bit unsure. On 
the video it seems like a you bearly tightened them but my castle nuts 
screw in far below the castle nut and the pin would go round the thread. 
Any advice? ﻿
comments.author: Lourens Riekert

comments.text: +Lourens Riekert Look in the service manual for the torque specs.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: BRO! Your initial yanks were in the wrong direction! LOL﻿

I have to replace the inner tie rod and your video helped me understand how

comments.text: +penny marie Awesome! Glad the video was helpful Penny!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
when i change the outer tie rods, in order not to move the nut I'd put a 
piece of masking tape on the other side of the nut and mark with a sharpie. 
that way you won't need a wheel alignment after﻿
comments.author: Vu nguyen

comments.text: +Vu nguyen Thanks for the tip!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Question. My Dodge's inner Tie Rods dont come off with a removal tool 
apparently. Theres nothing to grab it with. It does however have a plastic 
lock of some sort.

Its an old Stratus (Chrystler Sebring) 2000.
How are these tie rods removed?﻿
comments.author: Pedro Valenzuela

comments.text:
+Pedro Valenzuela You will need this which grips the round inner tie rod: 
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0066PI154/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B0066PI154&linkCode=as2&tag=chri0e2-20&linkId=IRCHM7WPFTQIKRUK

comments.text: good job,now I know.tks﻿

comments.text: +peter fish Great! Glad the video was helpful!

comments.text: Great video... thanks for sharing!﻿

comments.text: +Carey Green Thanks and no problem! Glad the video was helpful!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Great video! You provide outstanding detail. I'm sure someday It will help 
me save some $$. This one is being saved to my DIY playlist. Thanks!﻿
comments.author: GsP1979

comments.text:
1:38, the tool you mentioned is called a pickle fork, and you can get one 
for about $10. They are useful for separating other joints too.
I had to get one when I changed my tie rod ends because they were so 
severely stuck (nothing I had would work at all). And even that still 
didn't work until after I sprayed a bunch of WD-40 into it and let it soak 
for several minutes.﻿
comments.author: absol

comments.text: very good step by step video. very well made. thank you very much﻿
comments.author: benoit lambert

comments.text: +benoit lambert Thank you and no problem!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Hey Chris I watch a lot of your videos I just watch one of your how to 
change your serpentine belt and I did it all by myself but I'm now I'm 
changing my inner tie rod I thought it would be easy but I took the first 
clamp off the boot that's in the front now I'm trying to get to the back 
lamp and it looks like it's not showing one I have a 2001 Oldsmobile Alero 
I'll ask my cousin to come and help me I don't know what the heck is going 
on﻿
comments.author: samone jones

comments.text:
+samone jones Awesome man! The clamp might have fallen off. Does the boot 
move?
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: Amazing video! Thanks! I'm hoping to try this on an '84 f-150﻿
comments.author: mitch johnson

comments.text: +mitch johnson Thanks a lot! Let me know how it goes!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Nice video , but I have one question , is it not a good way to take off and 
mock up with new , to unbolt from knuckle and steering rack , then lay the 
old and new up against each other to measure up correct length ? Also , my 
old outer tie rods where fused to the inner , so I had to cut them to get 
off the boot.﻿
comments.author: tinnsoldaten

comments.text:
+tinnsoldaten You could do that. In the end, you will need an alignment no 
matter what so you are just trying to get it as close as possible,
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
My outer tie rod doesn't spin freely as suggested in the video. Help! It 
won't come loose.﻿
comments.author: Alan Rhines

comments.text:
+Alan Rhines You might need to use penetrating fluid, use a torch, or cut 
it off. Here is some awesome penetrating fluid: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2WuVBFTzoKc
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+ChrisFix Im gonna be honest here: I'm not a fan of putting old, grimy and 
greasy parts (Like the nut) on brand new shiny parts cause i prefer the 
parts put on clean for the looks. And it looks way better IMO. I have done 
this before, it just looks wrong to me. Whats your opinion on this Chris? 
No offense intended.﻿
comments.author: Peter Kapica

comments.text:
You are right, you can buy the same nut at the hardware store for about a 
buck or too for those picky ones
comments.author: Peter Kapica

comments.text:
+Peter Kapica As stated in the video, the old nut is larger and has more 
threads so it will hold the alignment better. I care more about how it 
works then how it looks for something as important as your steering 
components.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: thanks a lot Chris..I enjoy your videos..very helpful. God bless you.﻿

comments.text: +Paul Jason No problem Paul! I am glad the video was helpful!

comments.text:
Awesome video! Both my inner & outer tie rods are shot & had no idea how to 
replace them! Thanks!﻿

comments.text:
If you're replacing both inner and outer tie rods, why not just leave the 
outer on and remove the inner with them together?  That way you could 
assemble your new rod ends side by side and get the length just about 
perfect.﻿

comments.text: Thank you for such a clear, concise video! It was so helpful!﻿

comments.text: +Emma Dalton No problem! Glad the video was helpful!

comments.text: +Michael Payne About $80
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: I read you have to lock the steering rack how do you do that﻿
comments.author: NickandNature

comments.text: thanks i just went and had it done at a buddy shop for $100
comments.author: NickandNature

comments.text:
+NickandNature turn the car off, and take the key out of the ignition. Then 
turn the wheel until it clicks and locks.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
I have a question. How do you remove the inner tie rod end if the bolt is 
stripped? My inner-tie-rod-end does not have a pin in it, and yet I have 
managed to strip it with the special inner-tie-rod-end removal kit from 
Advanced Auto Parts which makes me wish I got the one from Auto Zone, but I 
trusted Auto Parts to much. I even used liquid wrench on it multiple times, 
but I got the same end result. I pretty much screwed myself out of having a 
car at this rate so I really need some hefty helpful advice. I will 
appreciate it if I got it as soon as possible.﻿
comments.author: Ikkaku572

comments.text: +Ikkaku572 Good luck and let me know when you get it out!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+ChrisFix Okay. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to use that tool at all, so I 
had no choice but to take it back. I have been having to use the butane 
blow torch, but turns out, I need a more powerful one.

I have a better Inner Tie Rod End remover tool, but I didn't want to use it 
on the side where I stripped the bolt. So, I moved to the passenger side. 
The boot is in fine condition, but clearly the tie rod on that side needs 
to be change out. The outer tie rod is stuck on that side. I need to get a 
more powerful torch because the other one I have is taking to long.
comments.author: Ikkaku572

comments.text: Okay, you have a point.
comments.author: Ikkaku572

comments.text:
+Ikkaku572 You are my student. I will teach you something new every week 
though YouTube!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+Ikkaku572 Never mind. I just thought of it. I have a weird socket that 
came with my inner-tie-rod-end removal kit. It will be perfect for that 
clamp tool that you just showed me. Thanks a lot! You are a life saver. It 
is to bad that there is a high possibly that we don't live close by to each 
other because I will be more than willing to become your student.
comments.author: Ikkaku572

comments.text:
+ChrisFix That's great and all, but what attachment do I use? I can't find 
anything that fits on there.
comments.author: Ikkaku572

comments.text:
+Ikkaku572 You can use an inner tie rod tool like this that clamps onto the 
stripped inner tie rod like this: 
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0066PI154/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B0066PI154&linkCode=as2&tag=chri0e2-20&linkId=2UBQCJ5QXI2VJ2BC
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
thank you for the video but you did not care of the excessive length of the 
rod and i think that will make a steering problem﻿
comments.author: Mabrouk Seleem

comments.text:
+Mabrouk Seleem You have to take the car in for an alignment anyway so you 
just want to get it close to the normal toe.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Just used your video to help replace both inner and outer tie rod ends. 
This saved me a ton of headaches. Thanks!﻿
comments.author: Ze26

comments.text: +Ze26 AWESOME! That is what I like to hear! Glad the video was helpful!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: We call that a track-rod end and a steering rod in the UK!﻿
comments.author: Mac McKay

comments.text:
Very thorough Chris I really like your style in your vids. Just 1 tip for 
everyone though that will save you $$ and time if you have a European car. 
For your outer tie rods and sway bar endlinks, make sure you use a 
counterhold!!! Some cars (like mine) dont use cotterpins so its just the 
bolt. Well mine was so tight that instead of loosening the nut from the 
threads, the entire ball assembly in the tie rod starting twisting instead. 
An entire day of cutting it off then a new $50 tie rod just because I 
forgot to counterhold it.﻿
comments.author: P2R_VOLV

comments.text: +P2R_VOLV Thanks and thanks for the tip!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
chris  coulndnt  I just use a large screw type clamp on the inner tie rod 
end ? could it be that its too wide ?  or would that work?﻿
comments.author: posneg1970

comments.text:
+posneg1970 You could but you have to find narrow ones because the normal 
one is too wide for the spot on the boot. Good thinking!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Right on Chris You are very Clear and your details are great so thank you 
very much for your help .﻿
comments.author: Mark Chance

comments.text: +Mark Chance Thanks Mark! I am glad the video was helpful!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
I'm looking at replacing mine, I want to do it myself. I thought you did a 
great job explaining things, and how to do it, and made it look pretty 
easy. Thanks for the video!﻿

comments.text: Wd40 isn't a lubricant it's a solvent lol! 😃﻿
comments.author: MadMetalManiac74

comments.text: +MadMetalManiac74 Yep.
comments.author: Jay Carlson

comments.text: +Jay Carlson that's really the best stuff imo. And cheap!
comments.author: MadMetalManiac74

comments.text:
+MadMetalManiac74 Yeah 30 years exactly. It's the Army Standard. However 
these days, I lube my ARs, AKs, and VZ58 with Mobile one oil and grease.
comments.author: Jay Carlson

comments.text:
+Jay Carlson lmfao! "facepalm" 😛. Terrible lube! Keep in mind any "liquid" 
will make things slippery just about. Doesn't mean that it's the correct 
product to use. Again clp is a mild lubricant. That is all. Not sufficient 
lubrication. It's primarily used for breaking up carbon buildup.
comments.author: MadMetalManiac74

comments.text:
+MadMetalManiac74  *lubing a bolt carrier with clp* I've done that for 
years. LOL!
comments.author: Jay Carlson

comments.text:
I mean don't get me wrong but wd40 as a dedicated lube is like lubing a 
bolt carrier with clp lol 😃
comments.author: MadMetalManiac74

comments.text:
Doesn't change the fact that it's a terrible lubricant and is majorily used 
for degreasing and cleaning parts. It's a mild lubricant at best. ﻿ which 
he was in fact doing in this vid. He was degreasing the shaft so the boot 
would slide off easier. Not that is was lubed persay. ﻿i remember back in 
the day it was even printed on the can.
comments.author: MadMetalManiac74

comments.text:
WD is water displacement spray
http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/WD-40 
There is oil in it

comments.text: WD stands for Water Displacement.

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
You said the new inner tie rod was slightly longer and you were getting a 
alignment afterward. I think if you measured the from the lock nut to the 
very end of the old tie rod may have been a little more accurate them 
counting how many spins on and off. Just saying. Or even a tape measure 
alignment may have been good. But that's a whole other video idea.﻿
comments.author: Michael Hanson

comments.text:
+Michael Hanson Thanks for the tip Michael. You need to get an alignment 
after you are done no matter what so counting the threads will get you 
close enough.

comments.text:
What's your thoughts on replacing tie rod end boot as oppose to the whole 
tie rod?﻿
comments.author: Hmm

comments.text:
+Hmm If the boot is ripped and you see it right away you can change the 
boot, but if the rip has been there for a while then it gets dirt and grit 
in there so you should replace the whole tie rod end. Usually tie rod ends 
are cheap and just worth to replace.

comments.author: Rob W

comments.text:
1st-thank you so much for this informative video!  I about cried when I got 
the estimate from the shop today.  

2nd- Just to clarify.......you do thread on the Tie rod itself all the way?

3rd-Would it hurt anything to use a conventional hose clamp to hold on the 
boot.  

Again, Thank you so much.  I'm seriously breathing a sigh of relief now. 
 And, my wife wife will think I'm awesome for fixing the car.  :)﻿
comments.author: jrloopy1984

comments.text:
+jrloopy1984 I am glad the video was helpful! You thread the the tie rod 
end on the inner tie rod based on turns. Like in the video, count the 
amount of turns and go off of that. You will need an alignment when you are 
done. 
You can use a hose clamp if it fits. That would work! Let me know how it 
goes!

comments.text:
+Shantkumar Daniel The procedure is the same. Does the inner tie rod have a

comments.author: Lance Stancliffe

comments.text: +Lance Stancliffe Thanks Lance!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Hey Chris, the inner tie rod (driver side) in my truck clunks when I rock 
the front up and down. It took me some time to find where the noise was 
coming from but I found it! Anyway,now that I know what the problem is I 
was wondering, do I need to change the outer tie rod as well? Also should I 
do the passenger side as well? The truck has 85K miles. Thanks!﻿
comments.author: Arturo Torres

comments.text:
+ChrisFix I should get one of those! I'm gonna ask around, see where I can 
get one with lifetime warranty or at least 6 months like you said. The one 
I got was for 90 days and it's been 4 months since I last aligned it... One 
month too late I guess...Story of my life!
comments.author: Arturo Torres

comments.text:
+Arturo Torres Yea, I got a lifetime alignment for my truck bc I knew I 
would use it. An alignment costs so much! Check your warranty on the 
alignment because sometimes they will realign within 6 months if it doesnt 
feel right!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+ChrisFix I'll jack up the truck tomorrow morning to see how bad it is. If 
there's a lot of play I might end up changing them next week. I wish I 
didn't have to align it again though!
comments.author: Arturo Torres

comments.text:
+Arturo Torres I would be careful because I dont know how bad the inner tie 
rod is. If that fails you will lose control of your car!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+ChrisFix Thanks! Will definitely do! I'll change them next month though, 
since I just got a new IAC valve and spark plugs/wires. It can wait a 
month, right?
comments.author: Arturo Torres

comments.text:
+Arturo Torres It might have been a bad tie rod and it just wore out. 
Pot-holes and curbs are common causes for tie rod damage but it sounds like 
yours just went bad. I think your shocks are fine and it sounds like the 
rest of your suspension is brand new so I would replace both sides.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+ChrisFix no idea. I replaced both lower ball joints and upper control arms 
a few months ago and there was no noise coming from the tie rods. Could it 
be that I need firmer shocks? I have the cheap blue Monroes...
comments.author: Arturo Torres

comments.text:
+Arturo Torres I would change the outer tie rod as well just so you wont 
have to bother with tie rods anymore. And I would do the other side as well 
since you will need an alignment. Get it all done so you wont have to worry 
about anything. That is what I personally do. You can get away with 
changing only the inner tie rod but I dont recommend that personally. Do 
you know what caused the inner tie rod to go bad (pot hole, curb?)
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Don't know if anyone mentioned this. The clamp on the inner boot is called 
an Oetiker. If you look close to the point where you squeeze it you will 
see a number. This tells the size of it. Second is when you change out tie 
rod ends I was taught that you measure from a place on the shaft to the 
center of the back side of the tie rod end (typically where the grease zerk 
would go). Now it doesn't matter if the new tie rod is different, it will 
come out the same.﻿

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: do you NEED the torque wrench? does it matter so long as its snug?﻿
comments.author: Caleb Rinker

comments.text: +ChrisFix​ thank you!
comments.author: Caleb Rinker

comments.text:
+Caleb Rinker You dont "need" a torque wrench, but it is highly recommended 
so the bolts/nuts are not too tight or too loose. Here is an inexpensive 
torque wrench that will last you for years: 
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00C5ZL0RU/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B00C5ZL0RU&linkCode=as2&tag=chri0e2-20&linkId=H5VVNFDPRJVMQ4RN
comments.author: ChrisFix
